docs.text:

    Motion, forces, energy, momentum, and rotational dynamics

    Start Learning

    Explore Waves

    Study Heat

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
Interactive Learning

  • 📐 Mathematical rigor with full LaTeX equation support
  • 🎯 Practice problems and worked examples
  • 🧪 Interactive simulations for key concepts
  • ✅ MCQs for self-assessment

Sample Equation

The famous mass-energy equivalence:

\[E = mc^2\]

Where \(E\) is energy, \(m\) is mass, and \(c\) is the speed of light.

docs.title: How to Use This Site
docs.text:
1. Follow the chapters in order, matching University Physics structure
  2. Study the theory with step-by-step derivations
  3. Work through examples before attempting problems
  4. Test yourself with MCQs and practice questions
  5. Explore simulations to build physical intuition
"The important thing is not to stop questioning. Curiosity has its own reason for existing." — Albert Einstein

docs.title: About Physics Daily
docs.text:
Welcome to Physics Daily!

This website is a comprehensive resource for studying physics, following the structure of "University Physics" by Sears & Zemansky.

docs.title: Our Mission
docs.text: To provide accessible, high-quality physics education materials for students and enthusiasts worldwide.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: If you have any questions or suggestions, please feel free to reach out.

docs.title: Physics Resources
docs.text: Here is a curated list of resources to help you on your physics journey.

docs.title: Part 4: Electromagnetism
docs.text:
Chapters 21-32 of University Physics

Electromagnetism covers electric and magnetic fields, circuits, and electromagnetic waves—the foundation of modern technology.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 21 Electric Charge and Electric Field 22 Gauss's Law 23 Electric Potential 24 Capacitance and Dielectrics 25 Current, Resistance & EMF 26 Direct-Current Circuits 27 Magnetic Field and Magnetic Forces 28 Sources of Magnetic Field 29 Electromagnetic Induction 30 Inductance 31 Alternating Current 32 Electromagnetic Waves

docs.title: Key Concepts Preview
docs.text:
Fundamental Equations

Coulomb's Law: \(\(F = k\frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2}\)\)

Gauss's Law: \(\(\oint \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{A} = \frac{Q_{enc}}{\epsilon_0}\)\)

Faraday's Law: \(\(\mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi_B}{dt}\)\)

Maxwell's Equations unify all of electromagnetism!

docs.title: Part 1: Mechanics
docs.text:
Chapters 1-14 of University Physics

Mechanics is the foundation of physics, dealing with motion, forces, energy, and the interactions between objects.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 1 Units, Physical Quantities & Vectors 2 Motion Along a Straight Line 3 Motion in Two or Three Dimensions 4 Newton's Laws of Motion 5 Applying Newton's Laws 6 Work and Kinetic Energy 7 Potential Energy & Conservation 8 Momentum, Impulse & Collisions 9 Rotation of Rigid Bodies 10 Dynamics of Rotational Motion 11 Equilibrium and Elasticity 12 Fluid Mechanics 13 Gravitation 14 Periodic Motion

docs.title: Key Equations Preview
docs.text:
Fundamental Equations

Kinematics: \(\(v = v_0 + at \qquad x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)\)

Newton's Second Law: \(\(\vec{F} = m\vec{a}\)\)

Work-Energy Theorem: \(\(W_{net} = \Delta K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - \frac{1}{2}mv_0^2\)\)

Conservation of Energy: \(\(K_1 + U_1 + W_{other} = K_2 + U_2\)\)

Start with Chapter 1: Units, Physical Quantities & Vectors →

docs.title: Chapter 3: Motion in Two or Three Dimensions
docs.text: Content coming soon!

docs.title: Key Topics
docs.text:
• Position and velocity vectors
  • Acceleration vector
  • Projectile motion
  • Circular motion
  • Relative velocity

docs.title: Preview: Key Equations
docs.text:
\[\vec{r} = x\hat{i} + y\hat{j} + z\hat{k}\] \[\vec{v} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}\] \[\vec{a} = \frac{d\vec{v}}{dt}\]

Projectile Motion:

\[x = v_0 \cos\theta \cdot t\] \[y = v_0 \sin\theta \cdot t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\]

← Previous | Next →

docs.title: Chapter 2: Motion Along a Straight Line
Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After studying this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Define displacement, velocity, and acceleration
  • Derive and apply kinematic equations
  • Analyze motion with constant acceleration
  • Solve free-fall problems

docs.title: Displacement
docs.text:
Displacement is the change in position:

\[\Delta x = x_2 - x_1\]

Displacement ≠ Distance

Displacement is a vector (has direction). Distance is the total path length traveled (always positive).

docs.title: Average Velocity
docs.text: \[v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}\]

docs.title: Instantaneous Velocity
docs.text: \[v = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{dx}{dt}\]

docs.title: Average Acceleration
docs.text: \[a_{avg} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_2 - v_1}{t_2 - t_1}\]

docs.title: Instantaneous Acceleration
docs.text:
\[a = \frac{dv}{dt} = \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}\]

Signs Matter!

  • Positive acceleration doesn't always mean speeding up
  • If \(v\) and \(a\) have the same sign → speeding up
  • If \(v\) and \(a\) have opposite signs → slowing down

docs.title: 2.3 Constant Acceleration: Kinematic Equations
docs.text:
When acceleration is constant, we have four key equations:

$$v = v_0 + at$$ $$x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$$ $$v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)$$ $$x - x_0 = \frac{1}{2}(v_0 + v)t$$

docs.title: 2.4 Free Fall
docs.text:
An object in free fall experiences only gravitational acceleration:

\[a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\]

(negative because downward, if we take up as positive)

Key Insight

All objects fall with the same acceleration regardless of mass (in the absence of air resistance). This was famously demonstrated by Galileo.

docs.title: Position-Time Graph (\(x\) vs \(t\))
docs.text:
• Slope = velocity
  • Curved line = acceleration present

docs.title: Velocity-Time Graph (\(v\) vs \(t\))
docs.text:
• Slope = acceleration
  • Area under curve = displacement

docs.title: Acceleration-Time Graph (\(a\) vs \(t\))
docs.text: • Area under curve = change in velocity

docs.title: Worked Example
docs.text:
Problem: A Car Stopping

A car traveling at 25 m/s applies brakes and decelerates at 5.0 m/s². How far does it travel before stopping?

Given:

  • \(v_0 = 25\) m/s
  • \(v = 0\) (car stops)
  • \(a = -5.0\) m/s² (negative because decelerating)

Find: \(\Delta x = ?\)

Solution:

Use: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a\Delta x\)

\[0 = (25)^2 + 2(-5.0)\Delta x\] \[\Delta x = \frac{625}{10} = 62.5 \text{ m}\]

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Key Equations

Quantity Definition Velocity \(v = \frac{dx}{dt}\) Acceleration \(a = \frac{dv}{dt}\) Free-fall acceleration \(g = 9.8\) m/s²

docs.title: Practice Problems
docs.text:
Problem 1: Acceleration

A car accelerates from rest to 30 m/s in 6 seconds. What is its acceleration?

Solution \[a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} = \frac{30 - 0}{6} = 5.0 \text{ m/s}^2\] Problem 2: Free Fall

A ball is dropped from a height of 45 m. How long does it take to reach the ground?

Solution

Using \(y = y_0 + v_0 t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) with \(y = 0\), \(y_0 = 45\) m, \(v_0 = 0\):

\[0 = 45 - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2\] \[t^2 = \frac{90}{9.8} = 9.18\] \[t = 3.03 \text{ s}\]

← Previous: Units & Vectors | Next: Motion in 2D/3D →

docs.title: Chapter 4: Newton's Laws of Motion
docs.text: Content coming soon!

docs.title: Key Topics
docs.text:
• Newton's First Law (Inertia)
  • Newton's Second Law (\(\vec{F} = m\vec{a}\))
  • Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction)
  • Free-body diagrams

docs.title: The Three Laws
docs.text:
Newton's Laws

First Law: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with constant velocity, unless acted upon by a net force.

Second Law: \(\(\vec{F}_{net} = m\vec{a}\)\)

Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. \(\(\vec{F}_{A \text{ on } B} = -\vec{F}_{B \text{ on } A}\)\)

← Previous | Next →

docs.text:

docs.title: Chapter 1: Units, Physical Quantities, and Vectors
Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After studying this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Describe the nature of physics and its relation to other sciences
  • Use SI units and convert between unit systems
  • Understand uncertainty and significant figures
  • Use vectors and their components

docs.title: 1.1 The Nature of Physics
docs.text:
Physics is an experimental science that seeks to understand the fundamental laws governing nature. It provides the foundation for all natural sciences and engineering.

Physics in Action

Everything from your smartphone's GPS to nuclear power plants relies on principles discovered through physics.

docs.title: 1.2 SI Units
docs.text:
The International System of Units (SI) defines seven base units:

Quantity Unit Symbol Length meter m Mass kilogram kg Time second s Electric Current ampere A Temperature kelvin K Amount of Substance mole mol Luminous Intensity candela cd

docs.title: Derived Units
docs.text:
Many physical quantities are expressed as combinations of base units:

\[\text{Force: } 1 \text{ N} = 1 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m/s}^2\] \[\text{Energy: } 1 \text{ J} = 1 \text{ N} \cdot \text{m} = 1 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}^2\]

docs.title: Unit Prefixes
docs.text: Prefix Symbol Factor giga G \(10^9\) mega M \(10^6\) kilo k \(10^3\) centi c \(10^{-2}\) milli m \(10^{-3}\) micro μ \(10^{-6}\) nano n \(10^{-9}\)

docs.title: 1.3 Unit Consistency and Conversions
docs.text:
Always Check Units!

Equations must be dimensionally consistent. If the units don't match on both sides, something is wrong.

docs.title: Example: Unit Conversion
docs.text:
Convert 60 miles per hour to meters per second:

\[60 \frac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}} \times \frac{1.609 \text{ km}}{1 \text{ mi}} \times \frac{1000 \text{ m}}{1 \text{ km}} \times \frac{1 \text{ hr}}{3600 \text{ s}} = 26.8 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}}\]

docs.title: 1.4 Uncertainty and Significant Figures
docs.text:
Every measurement has some uncertainty. We express this through significant figures.

Rules for Significant Figures:

  1. Non-zero digits are always significant
  2. Zeros between non-zero digits are significant
  3. Leading zeros are not significant
  4. Trailing zeros after a decimal point are significant

Significant Figures Examples

  • \(123.45\) → 5 significant figures
  • \(0.00123\) → 3 significant figures
  • \(1.2300\) → 5 significant figures
  • \(1000\) → ambiguous (use scientific notation: \(1.000 \times 10^3\))

docs.title: 1.5 Vectors and Vector Addition
docs.text: A vector is a quantity that has both magnitude and direction. We denote vectors with arrows or bold letters: \(\vec{A}\) or A.

docs.title: Vector Components
docs.text:
Any vector in 2D can be written in terms of its components:

\[\vec{A} = A_x \hat{i} + A_y \hat{j}\]

Where:

  • \(A_x = A \cos\theta\) (x-component)
  • \(A_y = A \sin\theta\) (y-component)
  • \(A = |\vec{A}| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2}\) (magnitude)
  • \(\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{A_y}{A_x}\right)\) (direction)

docs.title: Vector Addition
docs.text:
To add vectors, add their components:

\[\vec{C} = \vec{A} + \vec{B}\] \[C_x = A_x + B_x$$ $$C_y = A_y + B_y\]

docs.title: 1.6 Unit Vectors
docs.text:
Unit vectors have magnitude 1 and point in a specific direction:

  • \(\hat{i}\) points in the +x direction
  • \(\hat{j}\) points in the +y direction
  • \(\hat{k}\) points in the +z direction

Any vector can be written as:

\[\vec{A} = A_x \hat{i} + A_y \hat{j} + A_z \hat{k}\]

docs.title: Scalar (Dot) Product
docs.text:
The dot product gives a scalar:

\[\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = AB\cos\phi = A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z\]

Where \(\phi\) is the angle between the vectors.

Physical Meaning

The dot product tells us how much two vectors point in the same direction. Used in calculating work: \(W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{d}\)

docs.title: Vector (Cross) Product
docs.text:
The cross product gives a vector perpendicular to both:

\[|\vec{A} \times \vec{B}| = AB\sin\phi\] \[\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = \begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ A_x & A_y & A_z \\ B_x & B_y & B_z \end{vmatrix}\]

Right-Hand Rule

Point your fingers in the direction of \(\vec{A}\), curl them toward \(\vec{B}\), and your thumb points in the direction of \(\vec{A} \times \vec{B}\).

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Key Takeaways

  1. SI Units form the foundation of physics measurements
  2. Dimensional analysis helps verify equation correctness
  3. Vectors have both magnitude and direction
  4. Components: \(A_x = A\cos\theta\), \(A_y = A\sin\theta\)
  5. Dot product: \(\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B} = AB\cos\phi\) (scalar result)
  6. Cross product: \(|\vec{A} \times \vec{B}| = AB\sin\phi\) (vector result)

docs.title: Practice Problems
docs.text:
Problem 1: Unit Conversion

Convert \(9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\) to \(\text{km/hr}^2\).

Solution \[9.8 \frac{\text{m}}{\text{s}^2} \times \frac{1 \text{ km}}{1000 \text{ m}} \times \left(\frac{3600 \text{ s}}{1 \text{ hr}}\right)^2 = 127,008 \frac{\text{km}}{\text{hr}^2}\] Problem 2: Vector Addition

Vector \(\vec{A}\) has magnitude 5.0 and points 30° above the +x axis. Vector \(\vec{B}\) has magnitude 3.0 and points along the +y axis. Find \(\vec{A} + \vec{B}\).

Solution

Find components:

\(A_x = 5.0 \cos 30° = 4.33\)

\(A_y = 5.0 \sin 30° = 2.50\)

\(B_x = 0\), \(B_y = 3.0\)

Add components:

\(C_x = 4.33 + 0 = 4.33\)

\(C_y = 2.50 + 3.0 = 5.50\)

Magnitude and direction:

\(C = \sqrt{4.33^2 + 5.50^2} = 7.0\)

\(\theta = \tan^{-1}(5.50/4.33) = 51.8°\)

\(\(\vec{C} = 4.33\hat{i} + 5.50\hat{j}\)\) (magnitude 7.0 at 51.8° above +x axis)

Next: Motion Along a Straight Line →

docs.title: Part 6: Modern Physics
docs.text:
Chapters 37-44 of University Physics

Modern physics covers the revolutionary discoveries of the 20th century: relativity, quantum mechanics, and particle physics.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 37 Relativity 38 Photons and Matter Waves 39 Quantum Mechanics 40 Atomic Structure 41 Molecules and Condensed Matter 42 Nuclear Physics 43-44 Particle Physics and Cosmology

docs.title: Key Concepts Preview
docs.text:
Revolutionary Equations

Mass-Energy Equivalence: \(\(E = mc^2\)\)

Time Dilation: \(\(\Delta t = \gamma \Delta t_0 = \frac{\Delta t_0}{\sqrt{1 - v^2/c^2}}\)\)

de Broglie Wavelength: \(\(\lambda = \frac{h}{p}\)\)

Schrödinger Equation: \(\(i\hbar\frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t} = \hat{H}\Psi\)\)

docs.title: Part 5: Optics
docs.text:
Chapters 33-36 of University Physics

Optics explores the nature and behavior of light, including reflection, refraction, and wave phenomena.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 33 Nature and Propagation of Light 34 Geometric Optics 35 Interference 36 Diffraction

docs.title: Key Concepts Preview
docs.text:
Optics Fundamentals

Snell's Law: \(\(n_1 \sin\theta_1 = n_2 \sin\theta_2\)\)

Mirror/Lens Equation: \(\(\frac{1}{s} + \frac{1}{s'} = \frac{1}{f}\)\)

Double-Slit Interference: \(\(d\sin\theta = m\lambda\)\)

docs.title: Part 3: Thermodynamics
docs.text:
Chapters 17-20 of University Physics

Thermodynamics deals with heat, temperature, energy transfer, and the behavior of systems at the macroscopic level.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 17 Temperature and Heat 18 Thermal Properties of Matter 19 First Law of Thermodynamics 20 Second Law of Thermodynamics

docs.title: Key Concepts Preview
docs.text:
Fundamental Laws

Heat Transfer: \(\(Q = mc\Delta T\)\)

First Law of Thermodynamics: \(\(\Delta U = Q - W\)\)

Ideal Gas Law: \(\(PV = nRT\)\)

Entropy: \(\(\Delta S = \int \frac{dQ}{T}\)\)

Content coming soon!

docs.title: Part 2: Waves and Acoustics
docs.text:
Chapters 15-16 of University Physics

This section covers the physics of waves, including mechanical waves, sound, and wave phenomena.

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text: Chapter Topic 15 Mechanical Waves 16 Sound and Hearing

docs.title: Key Concepts Preview
docs.text:
Wave Fundamentals

Wave Equation: \(\(y(x,t) = A \sin(kx - \omega t + \phi)\)\)

Wave Speed: \(\(v = f\lambda = \frac{\omega}{k}\)\)

Sound Intensity Level: \(\(\beta = 10 \log_{10}\left(\frac{I}{I_0}\right) \text{ dB}\)\)
